The WorkOS Platform. Monday.com calls its platform a 'Work OS' (Work Operating System), where organizations can build software applications and work management tools that fit their needs. The platform is low-code/no-code and consists of modular building blocks that underpin a suite of products and features that customers leverage to deliver business value to their teams. The platform also integrates with other systems and applications, creating a connective layer for organizations that links departments and bridges information silos. See Exhibit 20. Below we list the different product that Monday.com offers. Exhibit 20: Monday.com WorkOS Platform Source: Monday.com FY25 Investor Day Presentation

Monday Work Management. The complete solution for connecting strategy to effective execution at scale, enabling customers to manage all aspects of work, such as daily tasks or entire projects, while collaborating and reporting updates in real-time in a centralized platform. Monday CRM. Fully customizable CRM solution, empowering business owners and sales teams to manage every aspect of their sales cycles and customer data. Features like email sync and tracking, post sales management, and sales operations equip organizations with the proper tools and resources needed to deliver satisfactory relationship management.

Monday Campaigns (generally available in 4Q25). A tool within Monday CRM that leverages AI to run email campaigns using customer data for marketing and sales teams. AI helps write content, target the appropriate audience, and determines the proper time to send outbound emails. Monday Dev. Enables product and development teams with the tools to seamlessly manage all development processes in a central platform. Features include sprint and product lifecycle management, along with agile reporting for customizable, real-time reports. Monday Service. Service teams are equipped with the tools needed to be proactive to different service requests. By leveraging a self-service knowledge portal, articles and tickets can be both accessed and created, and the entire lifecycle of a service ticket can be managed. Additional Products (can be used without the WorkOS platform):

 WorkCanvas. Digital whiteboard for real-time, unstructured collaboration.  Monday Workforms. Allows users to create personalized forms or surveys and gain organizational insights.  Guardian. Enterprise add-on for enhanced security and compliance, giving organizations more control over data protection, access, and oversight.

 Boards. At the core of the platform, boards hold any information and processes users have, within items and columns.  Items. Row within a board that represents anything a user decides for it to be, whether an entity, workstream or campaign, which can be populated with actions, steps, leads, etc.  Columns. Each item has any number of columns associated with it, and users can add columns to identify owners of an item or workstream, track a certain status, rate items, etc.  Views. Users can view and work with their data with multiple board view options, with each view built for a specified set of workflow needs.  Dashboards. Users can create dashboards with summaries and reports from data across multiple boards to track progress across their Monday.com ecosystem. o Dashboard Widgets. Users can select a dashboard widget best suited for their data with different visualizations.

 Automations. When certain thresholds are reached, users can automatically send notifications, create items, assign ownership, due dates, etc., to accelerate workflows.  Monday Workdocs. Enables users to work simultaneously on the same documents, and allows tagging, co-editing, commenting, drag and drop, etc., in real-time without disrupting others working in the doc.  Monday Workflows. Optimizes customer's automations and allows them to manage more complex workflows across different organizations, departments and products, which includes a workflow and connections center, robust workflow capabilities and an AI prompt to workflow feature.  Integrations. Allow users to connect with external tools to share data and automate across tools with integrations including Gmail, Outlook, Jira, Salesforce, Google Drive, Dropbox, Stripe, Slack, Github, Zendesk, etc.  Workspaces. Users can organize and centralize boards and dashboards defined by any category of their choosing.

 My Work. Allows users to view and manage all items assigned to them without needing to go back into individual boards.

Monday.com has introduced various AI capabilities to its customer base, which we outline below. Refer to Exhibit 21.

 Monday Magic. Allows users to describe their needs in natural language and auto-generate custom boards, columns, or functional workflows.  Monday AI Blocks. Modular AI capabilities within boards, columns, and automations that extract information and provide categorization, sentiment analysis, summarization, translation, etc.  Monday Vibe. Low code/no code app builder that allows users to create custom built business applications without writing a line of code.  Monday Sidekick. Virtual AI assistant that is contextually aware of user roles and provides suggested actions and recommendations.  Monday Agents (Generally available in 1H26). Multi-step autonomous agents that can execute entire workflows and tasks given out by the end user. o Agent Factory. Introduced in 4Q25 in Alpha, this is a standalone solution that lets anyone design and manage intelligent agents to automate complex workflows. These agents function as integrated team members by handling tasks like updating CRM records, sending emails, and scheduling follow-ups.

Source: Monday.com Investor Day 2025 Presentation (September 17, 20225)

MondayDB is the underlying data architecture that powers the Monday.com WorkOS platform, built from the ground up to support greater scale at speed for dashboards and boards, broader use cases, and custom workflows. According to management, MondayDB serves as a management layer that sits on top of other databases to provide controls over permissions/role-based access controls, automations, and triggers. For example, when different users change rows or roll up boards into a dashboard, or when a change to a field is set to trigger an event, MondayDB serves as the control plane. This has a significant compounding effect across Monday.com's various products. The company has announced three different versions since this new architecture was first introduced in 2023, which we describe below. Refer to Exhibit 22.

MondayDB 1.0 was introduced in 2023 to replace the company's previous architecture to support much larger and more complex workflows. This has enabled much greater performance, delivering up to 5x faster board loading, realtime data updates and support for advanced queries and automations. Beneath this infrastructure lies a schema-less architecture that separates compute and storage to optimize the greatest scale and flexibility needed for the Work OS platform.

Launched in 2024, MondayDB 2.0 was targeted at Enterprise accounts and shifted the focus from performance to scalability. This enabled greater support for larger dashboards and boards, with up to 100,000 items per board and 500,000 items per dashboard.

Within MondayDB 3.0, which is currently being rolled out, the focus is on providing additional scalability for new use cases and data volumes across the product portfolio. As of 3Q25, Work Management supports 1,000 projects in one portfolio. In 4Q25, as part of MondayDB 3.1, CRM will be able to handle 1M leads and contacts and 1,000 boards in a single dashboard, while MondayDB 3.2 (expected to be available in 2026) will enable 1M tickets in Service. Management is targeting to eventually get to 15 million contacts and leads for CRM and 15 million tickets in Service, which would significantly open up the large enterprise opportunity. Exhibit 22: MondayDB Release History and Roadmap Source: Monday.com website

This is Monday.com's in-house business intelligence tool that collects and processes data to deliver insights. It is built directly into Monday's Work OS platform to ease automation, data analysis, and smart suggestions in a centralized platform. By leveraging AI, BigBrain has the proper context for how teams across an organization operate, and can then provide real-time support through the automation of repetitive tasks, summarization tools, or the generation of content for emails and reports. BigBrain also helps power AI assistants and tools within Monday.com, bringing intelligent decision making and efficiency directly into the platform.

Self-Service  Outbound Sales. Monday.com's go-to-market motion has historically been a digital marketing driven, self-service sales approach but has been gradually shifting to more of an outbound enterprise sales-led motion. Traditionally, partly due to the non-technical nature of the product, users would sign up for the platform and immediately start gaining value. Adoption of additional Monday.com product SKUs or features from the marketplace, which are all built on the same platform, are seamless and require limited sales assistance. However, as Monday.com has expanded beyond SMB (<100 employees) and

mid-market (100-1,500) enterprises, buying decisions often involve the CIO and procurement teams, in addition to cross-departmental buy-in. Therefore, the company has expanded its outbound sales effort to better service these accounts, including more recently starting to offer targeted product bundles for different use cases. Account reps are specialized by region and customer size, with sales manager variable comp weighted more toward new logos and customer success variable comp weighted more towards retention stats. Monday.com has also invested in a partner channel, which include 266 active channel partners (up 8% y/y) and accounts for 20% of ARR today.

 Performance Marketing  SLG. Google AdWords currently represents less than 10% of New ARR. With the introduction of AI overviews in Google Search, Monday.com has begun shifting its performance marketing dollars from Google into other social/online channels and PLG opportunities. The company has also placed a greater emphasis on SLG initiatives, which typically have a cash payback period of 15-18 months, compared to performance marketing of 9-12 months. By leveraging the power of BigBrain, the company can track and identify campaigns to understand the value of each visitor and know which campaign brought in a lead.

 Targeted Upmarket Cross-Sell Strategy. As Monday.com has moved more upmarket, it recognizes that not all of its products are suitable for large enterprises, which typically already use a slew of software vendors. For mid-market enterprises, the company tries to sell Monday CRM and Service alongside Work Management. Meanwhile, for large enterprises that typically are deeply entrenched in Salesforce for CRM and also ServiceNow for ITSM, Monday.com tries to position Service for other departments outside of IT. In other words, it is trying to co-exist with some of the big software providers in the industry in the large enterprise. See Exhibit 23.

Monday.com's pricing is based on the plan tier and number of users. These tiers vary for Monday Work Management, CRM, Dev, and Service. Work Management comes in five separate editions (Free, Basic, Standard, Pro, Enterprise). CRM

and Dev come in Basic, Standard, Pro and Enterprise. Service is offered only for Standard, Pro, and Enterprise pricing. Payment can be made either monthly or annually. Today, more than 90% of Total ARR comes from the Pro and Enterprise tiers, including over 50% of Total ARR from the Enterprise tier. Meanwhile, 38% of New ARR is from the Enterprise tier vs. 25% at the time of the IPO in 2021. Larger customers typically need the security and scalability available only in the Enterprise tier. See a summary of what is included in each pricing tier and feature set below. We show prices for annual billing terms (prices for monthly billing terms are slightly higher).

 Free. Entry level offering aimed at individuals keeping track of their projects.  Basic ($9/User/Month). Has everything in the Free tier, plus unlimited boards/docs, increased storage, and simple dashboards.  Standard ($12/User/Month). Has everything in the Standard tier, plus timelines, calendar views, over 250 automations and integrations per month, as well as more granular AI features.  Pro ($19/User/Month). Has everything in the Pro tier, plus features such as more advanced workflows, private boards, time-tracking, formula columns, and over 25,00 automations and integrations per month.  Enterprise (Negotiated Directly). The most comprehensive Work Management offering with portfolio and resource management, enterprise-grade security, increased dashboards and priority support.

 Basic ($12/User/Month). Unlimited pipelines, contacts, boards, default lead/contact templates.  Standard ($17/User/Month). Has everything in the Basic tier, plus advanced contact and deal management, email integration, datadeduplication tools and greater automations and integrations.  Pro ($28/User/Month). Has everything in the Standard tier, plus forecasting and mass email tools, invoice capabilities, and further automations.  Enterprise (Negotiated Directly). The most robust CRM offering, which has greater lead insights, team goals, advanced dashboards and analytics, enhanced security and permissions, etc.

 Pro ($50/2,000 Contacts/Month). Pricing will vary depending on the number of contacts. This plan includes tools to grow and manage marketing campaigns, with features including a campaign manager and analytics, marketing segments, designed and account email templates, and dynamic content to personalize emails.  Enterprise (Negotiated Directly). Includes everything in Pro, plus greater emails/month per contact, a dedicated IP address, and automated email marketing with advanced workflow features.

 Basic ($9/User/Month). Designed for small developer teams and includes Kanban views, default developer centric templates, basic dashboards and limited storage.  Standard ($12/User/Month). Has everything in the Basic tier, plus timeline/Gannt views, sprint management, roadmap planning and more automations and integrations.  Pro ($20/User/Month). Has everything in the Standard tier, plus private boards, agile-reporting capabilities, custom roadmaps, and further integrations and automation features.  Enterprise (Negotiated Directly). The most comprehensive Dev team offering with enterprise grade security, automations and integrations, advanced reporting and analytics.

 Standard ($26/User/Month). Introduces unlimited tickets/request/email capture, shared inbox, customer portal access for up to 10 users and other integrations/automations.  Pro ($38/User/Month). Has everything in the Standard tier, plus autoresponse capabilities, customizable email server prefix, increased portal access to 100 users, and further dashboard enhancements.  Enterprise (Negotiated Directly). Offers multiple customizable email servers, unlimited user customer portal, multi-level enterprise grade security and permissions, advanced analytics and support, along with other features.

Thus far, Monday.com has launched the following AI features: Magic, Vibe, AI Blocks, Sidekick, Vibe, Agent Factory (part of broader Agents capabilities to roll out in 1H26). Other than Magic, which is included for free, all the other features

either are, or will be, priced based on usage. Certain AI features have different pricing structures, which we detail below:

 Monday Magic. Existing Monday.com users have access to Monday Magic, which is embedded directly into workspaces for no additional charge.  Monday Sidekick. Currently in Beta, there is no additional charge for using Monday Sidekick, but that may change in the future, according to the company.  AI Blocks. AI credits are charged per item, rather than per action. If multiple AI actions are on the same item within 24 hours, only one credit will be charged. Each account receives a one-time credit trial, which varies by tier. There are also built-in AI features that are free to use and require no credits, which include Summarization, Adding Columns, Filtering and Building Workforms. o Customers are given 750 credits for non-enterprise plans and 1,500 credits for enterprise plans. These AI credits are charged when any task that is intentionally set by a user is run, part of an automation cycle or using an AI-powered feature. Customers will then need to purchase additional credits to continue leveraging the power of Monday AI.

 Monday Vibe. Monday Vibe will be primarily charged per app built and price will vary depending on tier. See Exhibit 24.

Source: Monday.com 3Q25 Shareholder Letter -  Agent Factory (part of Monday.com Agents). This product can be accessed as a standalone offering outside of Monday.com. Agent credits are used when an agent performs an action; the number of credits used will depend on the type of task. Agents will be paused once the credit limit is reached and will only resume when additional credits are added. An additional 10,000 Agent Credits cost $99/month. See Exhibit 25.

Source: Monday.com Website

Contract and invoicing terms. Approximately 70% of contracts are one year in length, with the remainder multi-year (about 17%) or monthly (13%), as of 1H25. The mix of annual contracts has been relatively steady over the last couple of years. See Exhibit 26. Subscription revenue contracts are typically paid in full upfront at the outset of the arrangement.

Source: Monday.com FY25 Investor Day Presentation Revenue recognition terms. Customers are granted access to the software over the contractual agreement and are accounted for as service contracts. Revenue for these arrangements is recognized ratably over the length of the contract. ARR. Monday.com calculates ARR as the annualized value of customer subscription plans, assuming that any contract that expires during the next 12 months is renewed on its existing terms.

Gross Revenue Retention Rate. At its FY25 Investor Day, Monday.com detailed a slide highlighting the company's ongoing GRR improvement. Based on our conversations with management, Monday.com's SMB cohort accounts for 40% of ARR and a high 70s % GRR; its Midmarket cohort accounts for 30% of ARR and a mid-80s % GRR; and its Enterprise cohort accounts for 25% of ARR and a mid90s % GRR. Therefore, we believe Monday.com's Gross Revenue Retention Rate is in the mid-80s % as of 2Q25 and has increased approximately 800 bps over the last four years. See Exhibit 27. Exhibit 27: Monday.com Gross Revenue Retention Rate, 2Q21-2Q25 Source: Monday.com FY25 Investor Day Presentation

Net Dollar Retention Rate (NDR). Monday.com defines NDR as the percentage change in ARR derived from the customer base at a point in time. NDR at the end of period is calculated by starting with customers as of the 12 months prior to such period end, or the Prior Period ARR. ARR is then calculated for these customers as of the current period end, or the Current Period ARR. The calculation of Current Period ARR includes any upsells, price adjustments, user growth within a customer, contraction, and attrition. NDR is equal to Current Period ARR divided by Prior Period ARR. See Exhibit 28 for historical NDR. Exhibit 28: Monday.com Net Dollar Retention Rate, 1Q23-3Q25 Source: Monday.com company reports and Guggenheim Securities, LLC estimates

Medium Term (FY27) Targets. At its FY25 Investor Day in September 2025, management provided the following FY27 targets.  Revenue: $1.8B revenue target.  Non-GAAP gross margin: Incremental AI-related compute costs will moderate gross margins to mid-80%.

 Non-GAAP S&M % of revenue: Drive down to 40% as a percentage of revenue.  Non-GAAP R&D % of revenue: Continue to invest in organic innovation (AI, new products).  Non-GAAP G&A % of revenue: Drive efficiency through automation and streamlined internal workflows. Long-Term (FY30) Margin Targets. At its FY25 investor day, management also provided long-term targets (in about five years or by FY30) for both Non-GAAP operating margin of 20-25% and Adjusted Free Cash Flow of at least 30%.

At its FY25 Investor Day, CFO Eliran Glazer outlined a capital allocations plan that balances both investment into the business and the return of capital to shareholders. With regards to M&A, the company detailed that any potential acquisitions would mostly be tuck-ins aimed at accelerating the product roadmap and providing additional features and functionalities to enhance Monday CRM. Mr. Glazer said acquisitions in the tens of millions to $200M range would be most appropriate, and that Monday.com is not interested in acquiring revenue or customers. The company announced an $870M share repurchase program, targets keeping share repurchases below 10% of Monday.com's market cap, and is targeting 2% share dilution over the long term.

We employ a rigorous academic approach to a three-stage Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis to derive the intrinsic value of any Software stock, using conservative assumptions where appropriate. We typically assume a terminal period free cash flow (FCF) margin of about 35%, which we believe is about the FCF margin for a relatively mature Software company at scale that is growing at about the long-term growth rate of the economy. In other words, we assume the company is run relatively efficiently in the terminal period during which it has ceased trying to grow the company at elevated rates. For some companies, we may adjust this terminal FCF margin to account for anomalies in its financial model, such as third-party tolls not experienced by typical Software businesses, or in cases that have demonstrated higher FCF margins at steady state.

Our base case DCF analysis, which is based on FY25 guidance and consensus estimates, assumes a revenue CAGR of 18% from FY25-FY30 (the hyper-growth period) followed by linear deceleration in the transitionary period to reach 5% growth in the terminal period. We assume FCF margin (adjusted for stock-based compensation) expands from about 23% in FY25E to 35% in the terminal period where FCF reaches a steady-state 5% growth rate into perpetuity. Our base case yields an NPV/share of $237 about 55% above the current share price.

Our plausible case DCF analysis, on which we are basing our price target, assumes a revenue CAGR of 19% from FY25-FY30 (the hyper growth period) followed by linear deceleration to 5% in the terminal period. We assume the same FCF margins as in our base case, reaching 35% in the terminal period while FCF sustains 5% annual growth into perpetuity. Our plausible case yields a price target of $250, implying approximately 64% upside potential. See Exhibit 50.

Our $250 PT is based on a 3-stage DCF analysis and implies 8.0x EV/NTM Recurring Revenue (6.3x FY27E) and 28.3x EV/NTM FCF (21.9x FY27E), vs. current multiples of 4.4x NTM Recurring Revenue (3.5x FY27E) and 15.5x NTM FCF (12.0x FY27E). MNDY trades significantly below the average NTM multiples (based on consensus estimates) of 6.0x and 25.7x, respectively, for the average of eight Software peers that have lower revenue growth and FCF margin (FY26E revenue growth of 16% vs. MNDY's 21% and FY26E FCF margin of 22% vs. MNDY's 27%). In fact, MNDY shares are the least expensive on a

growthadjusted basis (2.0x vs. 3.6x peer average). Even if we assume 0% revenue and FCF growth in the terminal year, the DCF-implied price target is still about 20% higher than the current price. See Exhibit 45.

BUY (B) - Describes stocks that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of 10% or more within a 12-month period. NEUTRAL (N) - Describes stocks that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of between plus 10% and minus 10% within a 12-month period. SELL (S) - Describes stocks that we expect to provide a total negative return (price appreciation plus yield) of 10% or more within a 12-month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Guggenheim Securities, LLC policies. CS - Coverage Suspended. Guggenheim Securities, LLC has suspended coverage of this company. NC - Not covered. Guggenheim Securities, LLC does not cover this company. Monitor -Describes stocks whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Under Review (UR) Following the release of significant news from this company, the rating has been temporarily placed under review until sufficient information has been obtained and assessed by the analyst. Guggenheim Securities, LLC methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Price targets are assigned for Buy- and Sell-rated stocks. Price targets for Neutral-rated stocks are provided at the discretion of the analyst.
